message.content: This question requires knowledge about early humans and their observation of natural phenomena to predict growing and hibernation patterns. Early humans learned repeating weather patterns, star formations, and time intervals to make predictions about planting and harvesting times and when certain animals would hibernate. Option (C) is the correct answer because it states that early humans realized that one year consists of 365 days and nights, which allowed them to track the passage of time and make predictions about seasonal changes. Option (A) is incorrect because the sky is not always blue at night. Option (B) is incorrect because while many plants do take a year to grow, this knowledge alone would not be sufficient to make accurate predictions about planting and harvesting times. Option (D) is incorrect because the sun does not remain still for 12 months a year; its position in the sky changes throughout the year.

This question tests knowledge of how early humans used natural cues to understand the passage of time. By observing repeating weather patterns, star formations, and time intervals, early humans were able to predict planting and harvesting times, as well as the hibernation patterns of food animals. Option (A) is incorrect because the sky being blue at night is not relevant to the question. Option (B) is incorrect because not all plants take a year to grow. Option (D) is incorrect because the sun is not still for 12 months a year - it appears to move across the sky due to the Earth's rotation. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer, as early humans learned that one year consists of 365 days and nights through their observations and understanding of celestial patterns.

This question requires knowledge about how early humans observed natural phenomena to understand the passage of time. Early humans used repeating weather patterns, star formations, and time intervals to predict planting and harvesting times, as well as the hibernation patterns of food animals. Option (A) is incorrect because the color of the sky at night is unrelated to the observation of weather patterns and star formations. Option (B) is incorrect because not all plants take a year to grow, and early humans were likely observing shorter time intervals. Option (D) is incorrect because the observation that the sun is still for 12 months a year is not related to the passage of time or the prediction of natural cycles. Only option (C) accurately reflects the understanding that early humans gained about the passage of time through their observations.

Option (B) is also incorrect because the time it takes for plants to grow can vary depending on the species. Option (D) is incorrect because the sun appears to move across the sky throughout the year, rather than staying still for 12 months.
